title: Fall Armyworm (Spodoptera frugiperda)
text:
Origin & Spread: Native to the Americas; long present in the southern U.S., migrating north each summer.
Crops Affected: Maize, rice, sorghum, cotton, and 80+ others.
U.S. Distribution: Year-round in FL, TX, LA; seasonal migrants into the Midwest and Northeast.
Climate Profile: Thrives where mean temperatures > 15 °C; multiple generations per year in tropical/subtropical zones; migratory in temperate zones.
Phenology: Cumulative GDD base 10 °C; outbreaks when GDD > 400.
Impact: Globally causes 8–20 Mt maize loss annually; U.S. losses spike locally during high-density years.

title: Brown Marmorated Stink Bug (Halyomorpha halys)
text:
Origin & Spread: Accidentally introduced to mid-Atlantic U.S. in 1990s; now in 44 states and parts of Europe.
Crops Affected: Apple, peach, pear, corn, soybean, vegetables.
U.S. Distribution: Established in PA, MD, VA, and spreading westward and northward.
Climate Profile: Active 15–30 °C; overwinters as adult in sheltered sites; humidity > 50% favors survival.
Phenology: First flight at GDD ≈ 150 (°C base 12); peak damage when GDD 400–800.
Impact: 2010 outbreak caused ≈ $37 M tree-fruit losses in Mid-Atlantic alone.

title: Spotted-Wing Drosophila (Drosophila suzukii)
text:
Origin & Spread: Native to SE Asia; established in North America since 2008.
Crops Affected: Soft fruits—strawberry, raspberry, blueberry, cherry, grape.
U.S. Distribution: Pacific Northwest, Northeast, Midwest, Southeast.
Climate Profile: Prefers 20–25 °C and RH > 70%; can overwinter in mild climates and greenhouses.
Phenology: Multiple generations per season; peak oviposition when mean temps ≈ 22 °C.
Impact: Can cause up to 100% loss in unprotected berries; major quarantine pest.

title: Asian Citrus Psyllid (Diaphorina citri)
text:
Origin & Spread: Native to South Asia; now widespread in FL, TX, and CA citrus regions.
Crops Affected: All commercial citrus—orange, grapefruit, lemon, lime.
U.S. Distribution: Established in peninsular Florida, southern Texas, pockets of California.
Climate Profile: Development stops below ~15 °C; optimal survival at 25–30 °C, RH 60–80%.
Phenology: GDD base 10 °C; adults appear when GDD 200–300.
Impact: Vector of Huanglongbing (citrus greening), which kills trees within 2–5 years and reduces yields by > 50%.

title: Mediterranean Fruit Fly (Ceratitis capitata)
text:
Origin & Spread: Native to sub-Saharan Africa; established in southern California and periodic outbreaks in FL and TX.
Crops Affected: Citrus, stone fruits (peach, apricot), pome fruits (apple, pear), vegetables.
U.S. Distribution: Yearly detections in CA’s Central Valley; quarantine zones in FL.
Climate Profile: Prefers 20–30 °C, moderate humidity; intolerant of frost.
Phenology: One generation every 22–30 days at 25 °C.
Impact: Triggers multi-million-dollar eradication and quarantine programs in outbreak zones.

title: Mexican Fruit Fly (Anastrepha ludens)
text:
Origin & Spread: Native to Mexico/Central America; occasional introductions in southern Texas.
Crops Affected: Grapefruit, mango, peach, pear, figs.
U.S. Distribution: Sporadic interceptions and small infestations along U.S.–Mexico border.
Climate Profile: Subtropical; cannot overwinter where winter lows < 10 °C.
Phenology: Larval development ~20 days at 25 °C; three generations per year in Mexico.
Impact: Strict control measures—sterile insect technique and bait-spray programs to prevent establishment.

title: Diamondback Moth (Plutella xylostella)
text:
Origin & Spread: Likely from Europe; now cosmopolitan wherever brassicas grow.
Crops Affected: Cabbage, broccoli, cauliflower, kale, canola.
U.S. Distribution: Nationwide in cole-crop growing regions; migratory in temperate zones.
Climate Profile: Rapid development at 15–25 °C (generation ≈ 14 days at 20 °C); RH 60–80%.
Phenology: Generations overlap; peak populations in late spring and early fall.
Impact: ~$4–5 B annual global losses; severe economic pest of U.S. crucifer production.

title: Red Imported Fire Ant (Solenopsis invicta)
text:
Origin & Spread: Native to South America; introduced to southeastern U.S. in 1930s–40s; now in 13+ states.
Crops Affected: Soybean, corn, cucurbits, citrus; mounds disrupt planting/harvesting.
U.S. Distribution: FL, AL, MS, LA, TX, GA, SC, NC, TN, AR, OK, CA.
Climate Profile: Prefers 20–30 °C, humid; cannot survive extended freezes.
Phenology: Colony activity peaks at 25 °C; foraging increases with RH > 50%.
Impact: ≈ $5 B/year in damage and control; reduces soybean yields by 30–50 kg/ha via mound disturbance.
